thread.title: Paris train hero in critical condition after stabbing
thread.title_full: Paris train hero in critical condition after stabbing | Washington Examiner

author: Jacqueline Klimas
title: Paris train hero in critical condition after stabbing
text:
One of the heroes who stopped the Paris train attack in August was stabbed Wednesday night in Sacramento and remains in critical condition.
Airman 1st Class Spencer Stone was stabbed "repeatedly," according to multiple news reports.
"It is believed that the victim was out with a group of friends when a physical altercation led to the victim being stabbed multiple times in his upper body. Detectives were called to the scene to assist with the investigation and the victim is currently being treated for what appears to be non-life threatening injuries," Sacramento police said in a statement, without naming Stone. No arrests have been made.
The police department tweeted that the incident "is not related to a terrorist attack. Assault occurred near a bar, alcohol is believed to be a factor."
  German authorities storm VW offices The raid targeted documents and computers that would help the probe into VW's scheme to cheat emission rules
By John Siciliano • 10/08/15 11:14 AM Update: The assault incident is not related to a terrorist act. Assault occurred near a bar, alcohol is believed to be a factor.
— Sacramento Police (@SacPolice) October 8, 2015 Air Force Times reported that police initially treated the attack as a homicide because they didn't expect Stone to survive.
In August, Stone was one of three Americans who stopped a heavily armed gunman on a Paris-bound train, potentially saving hundreds of lives. Moroccan Ayoud El Khazzani had an AK-47, a lugar pistol, a box cutter and several hundred rounds of ammunition, according to Air Force reports.
Stone charged Khazzani, tackling him to the ground and knocking the would-be gunman unconscious before anyone was killed. Despite injuring his own thumb during the attack, Stone provided medical aid to a French passenger who had been shot after subduing the gunman.
Two other Americans also helped to stop the gunman: Oregon National Guardsman Spc. Alek Skarlatos and Anthony Sadler.
Also from the Washington Examiner Carter lashes out at Russia's 'unprofessional' behavior "We have seen increasing unprofessional behavior" by Russia, Carter said at a NATO meeting in Brussels.
By David Brown • 10/08/15 10:55 AM Skarlatos took to social media Thursday morning after news broke of the stabbing, urging followers on photo-sharing site Instagram to "send some prayers" to Stone.
Send some prayers out the the guy in the middle @spencthang 
A photo posted by Alek Skarlatos (@alekskarlatos) on Oct 8, 2015 at 8:28am PDT
The three childhood friends visited the Pentagon last month where Defense Secretary Ash Carter presented Stone with the Purple Heart for his injuries and the Airman's Medal , the highest award for bravery outside of combat.
"Thank you for acting," Gen. Paul Selva, vice chairman of the Joint Chiefs, said during the ceremony. "Thank you for being people who cared enough to make a difference."
Also from the Washington Examiner Whole Foods recalls contaminated Roquefort cheese The chain is recalling all of its cut, wrapped and weighed Papillion organic Roquefort cheese.
By Robert King • 10/08/15 10:58 AM The three Americans also received the Legion of Honor, France's highest award for valor, in the days following the attack.
Stone will be promoted two ranks to staff sergeant this month as a result of his actions.
Top Story McCarthy out of speaker's race GOP was set to hold an internal election Thursday afternoon, but that election was postponed.
By Susan Ferrechio • 10/08/15 12:30 PM
